physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "(Ezra)" in pencil at the top of first page. Amy Lowell's return address is provided in the top left corner: MISS A. LOWELL HEATH STREET BROOKLINE, MASS. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: Thanks for the letter. It took a load off my mind. I quite agree with you about correspondency, but I did want to know if you had got the poems. I am glad they are all going in.

The paper is looking up, I think; in the prose articles, I mean. Why did you get out of the direct control: A sacrifice to friendship, I imagine. You certainly make an excellent friend. By the way, I liked your friend Richard Aldington’s poem, "The Poplar," in current "Poetry," and it was a good idea, your getting Lawrence for her.
I am going out to Chicago next month, to try and make her publish some more of my things which she has, and also load some more on her, if possible.
You might send me half a dozen copies of "The Egoist" which contains my things, if you will, as it cannot be bought in this country.

I sent some of my things, the other day, to
"The Smart Set," with a personal note to Mr. Wright, whereupon they all came travelling home again, with a letter from another man, who made no sort of scruple in opening my letter, in spite of the docket, and who begged me to send him some more of my work. I now see by the papers that Mr. Wright is no longer editor, and they are harking back to the old policy of the magazine, so it is no wonder they refused my things, and I certainly don’t want to appear in it, if it is going to be the kind of magazine it used to was.
